Deviations from Arrhenius behavior gives to the γ function straight line dependence at small β a direction forming the δ angle, which it is connected to the d parameter of the Aquilanti-Mundim (AM) law. At low temperatures as the “coldness” variable β increases, the transitivity function tends to characteristic ultra-cold limiting values: (i) for d < 0 ( sub-Arrhenius) it tends to the Wigner limit and (ii) for d > 0 ( super-Arrhenius), γ, namely the propensity for reaction to occur, vanishes in β †, γ(β †) = 0: the corresponding energy and temperature parameters are denoted by a single dagger, ε †and T †, respectively, as detailed below.
